text:
Hey, <@U0361H80U8Y>, I work at an IM company, actually. So I write about this topic a lot. Typically brands measure in a few ways (and it depends on your goal). Is it awareness, conversions, sales, etc.?

*Typically the common goals would be:* 
1. Brand awareness
2. Find new audiences
3. Make/increase sales
4. Manage reputation
*Metrics that are most commonly tracked:* 
1. Revenue and conversions — pretty straightforward on this one. Did conversions explode the day of/days after an influencer post? Did you give them an affiliate link to share with their followers? Did you provide them with a coupon code to track sales? 
2. Pageviews and impressions — again, did traffic increase after the post. Did you give them a tracking link for their link in bio or an affiliate link to share, or are they simply hyping your company? Use landing pages and promo codes here to track.  
3. Engagement on social media posts
4. Number of new backlinks
Most IM platforms will also include/present you with a brand lift study, which is an incredibly valuable piece of data. It's hard to manage this manually; to be honest,  you'll want an IM analytics tool without it; you're using different platforms and data to tell a whole story.

elements.text: Hey,
, I work at an IM company, actually. So I write about this topic a lot. Typically brands measure in a few ways (and it depends on your goal). Is it awareness, conversions, sales, etc.?
Typically the common goals would be:
Brand awareness
Find new audiences
Make/increase sales
Manage reputation
Metrics that are most commonly tracked:

Revenue and conversions — pretty straightforward on this one. Did conversions explode the day of/days after an influencer post? Did you give them an affiliate link to share with their followers? Did you provide them with a coupon code to track sales?

Pageviews and impressions — again, did traffic increase after the post. Did you give them a tracking link for their link in bio or an affiliate link to share, or are they simply hyping your company? Use landing pages and promo codes here to track.
Engagement on social media posts
Number of new backlinks

Most IM platforms will also include/present you with a brand lift study, which is an incredibly valuable piece of data. It's hard to manage this manually; to be honest,  you'll want an IM analytics tool without it; you're using different platforms and data to tell a whole story.

text: Late to this party <@U02B60T1W83>, but we actually utilize webinars and podcasts to pull in customer testimonials/customer use cases. We do a "live podcast" via webinar where we talk to our customers about how they're using our platform, what strategies they're executing, results they're seeing, etc. Then we turn that into  a podcast/video show that's distributed across syndication channels, transcribed for quotes and written content, and we use video clips to share the content and within other written content. Hope that helps!

Hope that helps!

text: where I manage SEO (B2C/ecomm side), we actually see people interacting with it quite a bit, ESPECIALLY if Google decides to, ahem, show it in the indented results for brand searches — so it becomes a one-click entry point for searches around our brand name. but we're a membership model and so people may be seeking more information about the membership or business model generally. it's generally not the first introduction to the brand (if they're googling the brand anyway), so agree with the MoFu/BoFu classification, but can be a landing point for PAA queries as well

text:
I collect video testimonials regularly from my clients. I interview them using the 6 questions in this workbook: <https://stellarplatforms.s3.amazonaws.com/uploads/testimonials-101.pdf>

I record my clients answers in Speaker View on Zoom, and then I upload the video into Descript. With some clever copy/paste, I can make a tight paragraph of the best phrases they use. Then I follow this process:
1. Email the client and ask if the edits look okay
2. When they reply affirmative, I send a link to my LinkedIn profile and ask them to copy/paste it into a recommendation
3. I paste it into a Canva template for my testimonial images with their headshot
4. I use that image as the thumbnail to the YouTube video
This is what I create with that process: <https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PL5_mXBuGyqNQZXPIqjmmLkKhVWx4E8XR2>

That's my process. Hope that helps!

attachments.text: Video testimonials for Caelan Huntress, Creative Director of Stellar Platforms.
attachments.title: Testimonials

text:
Thanks for the tag <@U02QWSD3BSM>.

<@U019UEW7AQ2>, agency owner here :wave: We installed GA4 across the board but, are still using UA as the core reporting. Since GA4 is event driven there are some cool things you can do with it similar to using UA’s content grouping feature or even firing events based on scroll depth to inform reading % of content.

One thing I know I’ll be doing as well is warehousing GA4 into BigQuery, since there is a native connector, and then aggregating it with GSC data to gain deeper insight into performance.

elements.text: Thanks for the tag
, agency owner here

We installed GA4 across the board but, are still using UA as the core reporting. Since GA4 is event driven there are some cool things you can do with it similar to using UA’s content grouping feature or even firing events based on scroll depth to inform reading % of content.

One thing I know I’ll be doing as well is warehousing GA4 into BigQuery, since there is a native connector, and then aggregating it with GSC data to gain deeper insight into performance.

text:
GA4 + BigQuery + DataStudio/Retool is where it’s at. :fire:

We’ve been blending the data with GSC, our topic cluster, and Salesforce data to paint a picture from visitor to qualified pipeline and revenue. :partyparrot:

elements.text: GA4 + BigQuery + DataStudio/Retool is where it’s at.
We’ve been blending the data with GSC, our topic cluster, and Salesforce data to paint a picture from visitor to qualified pipeline and revenue.

Hope it helps :)
